qas.question: How does LaserDisc operation vary from DVD?

answers.text: the transport mechanism always obeys commands from the user

qas.question: What are "User Protected Options" on DVDs?

answers.text: where content protection code instructs the player to refuse commands to skip a specific part

qas.question: Where are User Protected Options commonly found on DVDs?
Which format, LaserDisc or DVD, gives the user the most control over playback?

context: <a3_0>LaserDisc<a3_0/> players can provide a great degree of control over the playback process. Unlike many DVD players, <a0_0>the transport mechanism always obeys commands from the user<a0_0/>: pause, fast-forward, and fast-reverse commands are always accepted (barring, of course, malfunctions). There were no "User Prohibited Options" <a1_0>where content protection code instructs the player to refuse commands to skip a specific part<a1_0/> (such as fast forwarding through <a2_0>copyright warnings<a2_0/>). (Some DVD players, particularly higher-end units, do have the ability to ignore the blocking code and play the video without restrictions, but this feature is not common in the usual consumer market.)
